sections.title: Progressive Taxation Basics
sections.content: In the U.S. federal system, income is segmented into brackets. Each bracket is taxed at a marginal rate that applies only to the dollars within that bracket. You might be in the 24% bracket, but that rate applies to the last portion of your income—not the entire paycheck. Knowing this helps you estimate your true tax cost when taking on freelance work, bonuses, or raises.

points.title: Marginal vs Effective
points.description: Marginal rate is the tax on the next dollar earned. Effective rate is total tax paid divided by total income—usually much lower.

points.title: Filing Status
points.description: Single, Married Filing Jointly, and Head of Household each have unique bracket thresholds that can materially change your bill.

points.title: Stackable Income
points.description: Ordinary wages, side-gig earnings, and short-term capital gains stack together, potentially pushing you into higher brackets.

sections.title: Bracket Example
sections.content: In 2025 a single filer owes 10% on the first $11,600, 12% on the next $35,450, and 22% on income between $47,050 and $100,525. Only income above $100,525 hits the 24% bracket.

sections.title: Why Planning Matters
sections.content: Small adjustments—maxing a pre-tax 401(k), timing a Roth conversion, or shifting deductions—can keep taxable income from spilling into a higher bracket. Understanding thresholds also helps you forecast net pay from bonuses or stock vesting, so you're not caught off guard at tax time.

sections.title: Map Your Bracket
steps: Pull last year's return or your latest pay stub to determine current taxable income.
Identify the marginal bracket you occupy based on filing status.
List upcoming income events (bonus, freelance, RSUs) and estimate their tax impact.
Note one lever—like increasing 401(k) contributions or funding an HSA—that could keep income in your desired bracket.

sections.title: Use IRS Tools
sections.content: Bookmark the IRS Tax Withholding Estimator to recalc your paystub withholding anytime life events shift your income.
